docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: No parent wants to leave children vulnerable to on-line pornographers (Op-Ed, Oct. 19). But are Internet filters, which block access to the national Planned Parenthood Web site, really the best way to protect them?

docs.lead_paragraph: Two drug companies named agencies yesterday to handle the introductions of new products. The Knoll Pharmaceutical Company, a unit of BASF A.G. in Mount Olive, N.J., named Foote, Cone & Belding in New York to introduce Meridia, a prescription weight-loss drug. Billings were estimated at $50 million. Foote, Cone, part of True North Communications, was awarded the account after a three-and-a-half-month review that also included Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York. A campaign will begin tomorrow with television commercials that carry the theme, ''You do your part. We'll do ours.''
docs.abstract: Knoll Pharmaceutical Co names Foote, Cone & Belding to introduce Meridia, prescription weight-loss drug; billings estimated at $50 million; Gynetics Inc names Nelson Communications to introduce Preven Emergency Contraceptive Kit; billings estimated at $30 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The birth control pill is pushing 40, and like many another veteran of the 1960's, it never looked so good. It is the Volkswagen Bug of drugs -- a sleekly remodeled version of the 1960 prototype, housed in a box full of old associations, but completely reconfigured inside and intended for a brand-new market. Today's pills use hormone doses that are a small fraction of what they once were. While not utterly risk-free, they are far safer than the original versions and remain among the most effective forms of birth control on the market.

headline.main: The Pill at 40: Renewed, Improved and in Its Prime

docs.abstract: Birth control pill is approaching its 40th anniversary; concerns raised in 1970's about side effects have been reduced through reformulation and screening; pill has been shown to have many health benefits beyond preventing pregnancy; tables (M)
docs.snippet: The birth control pill is pushing 40, and like many another veteran of the 1960's, it never looked so good. It is the Volkswagen Bug of drugs -- a sleekly remodeled version of the 1960 prototype, housed in a box full of old associations, but...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 10 years after giving birth, women who acted as surrogate mothers for infertile couples said they did not regret the role they played. But some felt sad and disappointed over the loss of contact with the children they bore, who were biologically their own. And many imagined that one day their children would find them, even though in some cases the children had no idea that they came into the world in any other than the usual way.
docs.abstract: Study finds that more than 10 years affer giving birth, women who acted as surrogate mothers for infertile couples say they do not regret role they played; but some say they feel sad and disappointed over loss of contact with children they bore, who are biologically their own (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his opposition to a requirement that Federal health plans cover contraceptives, Representative Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, shows a lack of understanding (front page, Oct. 14). You report that Mr. Coburn does not want Depo-Provera and intrauterine devices covered because he maintains that they interfere with fertilization and therefore cause abortions.

headline.main: Congress's Budget-Making: Not a Pretty Sight

docs.lead_paragraph: When Jill Clayburgh walks down a Manhattan street -- even now, 20 years after ''An Unmarried Woman'' -- she emanates an energetic hope and love of life that's contagious. But walking down the street, carrying groceries, is just about the most interesting thing her character is given to do in the first two episodes of ''Trinity,'' an NBC drama series that has its premiere tomorrow night. ''Trinity'' is about her five grown children. There are high hopes for this show because its executive producer is John Wells, the power behind ''E.R.'' But the new series doesn't immediately have anything of that show's ensemble strength or complexity, and it has already been criticized for perpetuating stereotypes of Irish-Americans. The McCallister children are a priest, a police officer, a union leader, a stockbroker and an alcoholic. And when they gather for Sunday dinner at their parents' apartment in Clinton, they bicker, hit one another over the head, then say grace, have meatloaf and drink beer from the bottle.

headline.main: A Big and Familiarly Irish New York City Family

docs.abstract: Anita Gates reviews Trinity, new NBC drama series starring Jill Clayburgh; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The rate of teen-age pregnancies in the United States has dropped to its lowest rate in two decades, according to a new report by the Alan Guttmacher Institute. While reports of the decline in teen-age births, and in overall abortions, have become familiar, there has been less attention to the underlying drop in teen-age pregnancy.

headline.main: Teen-Age Pregnancy Rate Drops in U.S., Report Says

docs.abstract: Alan Guttmacher Institute reports teen-age pregnancy rate in United States dropped to its lowest level in 20 years in 1995, 101 pregnances per 1,000 women ages 15 to 19, down from peak of 117 in 1990; preliminary data suggest drop is continuing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Every pregnant woman in the country should be checked for the AIDS virus as part of routine prenatal care, an expert panel said today in recommending a policy change that could further reduce cases of babies' being infected at birth. Pregnant women infected with the virus can greatly reduce the chances of passing it to their infants if they take anti-viral drugs, but many are not being tested. Under Federal guidelines, doctors are encouraged to counsel women about the virus and suggest an AIDS screening test. The new recommendations call for reducing the amount of pre-test counseling in many cases and informing women that they will be tested for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, unless they object.

headline.main: Panel Urges H.I.V. Tests For All Pregnant Women

docs.abstract: Institute of Medicine panel recommends every pregnant woman in United States be tested for AIDS virus as part of routine prenatal care; Dr Marie McCormick, panel chairwoman, says move would help prevent HIV infection in newborns and could be achieved without great deal of added cost, interview (M)
